text: Welcome back. My name is Sir and in
these videos I'm going to walk you
through some of the different animation

Engine. We're going to be using the ACOM
animation sample project to dive into
some files. And a quick reminder that if
you're just joining us, this is
technically the third set of videos in
this series. So if you want to get a
little bit more introductory stuff, be
sure to check out the videos that have
come before. Now, let's go ahead and
dive in to Unreal Engine. In this video,
I'm going to walk you through some of
the different features and tools we have
inside of Unreal's curve editor to
adjust our splines while we're
animating, including some of the shiny
new features that were introduced in
5.6. So, right now, I'm in shot 10, that
is inside the episodes folder, intro
beta shot 10 here. And this is the level
sequence that I'm in. So, here we've got
the character Beta brushing his teeth,
hanging out, and eventually being
notified that there are some robots
breaking into the compound. Now, in this
particular shot, I am actually looking
at the control rig subsequence. I've
talked about this in some previous
videos, but I've muted the baked
animation clip and I'm looking at the
control rig subsequence, which is what
allows me to see the actual rig driving
the character. So, right off the bat,
I'm going to go ahead and grab maybe the
head control. And we'll take a look at
the curve editor for this. So, here I've
got the head control. I've got the
different key frames that have been used
to animate the character. And here, I'll
click on my curve editor button. So,
here you can see we have some uh back
and forth on the rotate Z control. just
doing a little bit of the uh you know
this motion back and forth since he's
brushing his teeth. So right off the bat
we can take a look at some of the stuff
in our curve editor. I'll look at the
anim details panel over here on the
right and I'll filter the head control
by rotation Y and rotation Z. And we can
see that there are two curves each with
their own key frames. Now in this
particular case you can see that the
rotation in Y has a much smaller change
over here. This channel is responsible
for sort of the tilt of the head, where
the blue one, rotate Z, is this side to
side motion. Now, if you're ever looking
at a bunch of different channels, just
like we're looking at these two here,
you'll notice that sometimes the curves
can be really large and take up a lot of
the vertical space, and others might
have smaller changes with smaller
numbers, and therefore they end up being
a smaller percentage of your vertical
space of your screen real estate. So if
I go over to the view tab, I can switch
the view mode from absolute mode, which
has both of these curves share a graph
where zero is a consistent spot on this
entire graph and the key frames are
plotted along those points. I can switch
this view from absolute mode to
something like normalized mode. And what
that will do is maximize the vertical
screen space for each of these controls.
Rotation and Y takes as much vertical
space as possible. Rotation and Z does
the same. And when I have them both
selected, they're no longer sharing a
true zero and like plot graph for these
different splines, it's now just taking
anything I have selected and maximizing
its vertical space within the window.
So, it's called relative mode in Maya.
It's called normalized mode here in
Unreal. And it gives us a quick and easy
way to see whatever we have selected
just blown up so we can actually see the
data play out at the same time. Or maybe
you've got a bunch of stuff and you want
to see them independently, not
overlapping like we have here. And
that's one more view mode. We can go
back to the stacked view mode. And now
you can see the label and individual
drawings of each curve we have selected.
If I grab all these other ones, you'll
see that we have a bunch of different
things to scroll through. Although most
of these don't actually have animation
on them. So I'll go back to the two I
have here. Anyways, I'll go back over

can see we have a little bit more data
here. Here we've got three different
location or transformation curves to
look at. And then we've got some

selected my anim. You can see that we've
got a bunch of different curves to look

absolute. But if you are having a hard

and you're having to zoom in, using alt
and shift and right mouse click to
actually see, you know, this this detail
and this wiggliness here, then maybe
going to the normalized mode will help
because now everything gets to take just
a little bit more screen space to draw

sure that I'm not moving a key freely.
But if I hold shift and go up and down,
it'll lock it to the vertical axis. If I
hold shift while middle mouse dragging
sideways, I can lock it horizontally.
Similar things to Maya. This is kind of
what animators are looking for, right?
The same behaviors that we are used to
and comfortable with. But we have a lot
of other powerful tools as well. For

Some of those modes, for example, are
here inside this selection dropdown.
There are a bunch of different tools
available to us. So, if I select some of
these keys and just have them here,
Unreal is assuming that I can just kind
of middle mouse drag, move them around,
do whatever I'm going to do. But if I
switch the selection mode over to
transform, you'll see that we get a
little box selection tool. Now, this is
not a lattice. This is a scaling box.
And it'll scale from this by default
center anchor point. So, if I go ahead
and try to move one of these points,
you'll see that the entire curve will
scale from that that center point. Now,
this point can be moved. I can shift it
over here, maybe up into the corner. And
now when I do my scaling, it'll actually
scale from that spot, which is really,
which is very handy. If I hold control,
it'll show me some of the fall-off
options. And you can see that I'm kind
of changing the feathering for this
selection. There's a bunch of this stuff
here in the tool options as well of
upper, lower, left, right, bounds,
scaling, and the actual fall-off. So, if
you're trying to adjust your scaling and
you're transforming these keys as a
whole, you have some really interesting
options to do that. But let's keep going
because we've got some newer and more
exciting options such as jumping ahead
to the lattice tool. The lattice tool
will give you independent control of
each point on this box. So I can go
ahead and move this corner and you'll
see that I can move the entire curve
sort of skew it from that one point. So
I'm no longer scaling from a specific
pivot point. I'm more skewing the entire
curves based on my selection. I can grab
these edges as well and I can sort of
pull the whole thing up if I want to
skew the angle. And wherever I'm at, if
I double click on one of the edges, it
will collapse the keys to match that
edge, which can be very, very helpful,
especially if you're trying to just zero
something out. Boom. Done. So, that's
the new lattice tool that came out in
5.6. At the moment, we don't have a way
to add additional rows and columns, but
I think that's something that we'll
probably get in the future. Either way,
you do have the ability to just change
your selection and maybe grab, you know,
a smaller subset of keys to adjust and
continuously mess with from here. But I
want to give you two really useful
tools. If you've animated in the curve
editor a lot in Maya, Blender, or Unreal
Engine, you know that sometimes you're
copy pasting keys and when you paste a
curve, it's flipped from what you want.
The positives need to be negatives and
something that's moving up needs to move
down, something like that. Uh, there are
two ways I want to show you how to do
that really quick. First, if I select a
curve, the same trick we have in Maya
works here as well, which is that if you
were centered around zero, if your act
if your uh rotation axis, for example,
were just sitting on the sort of base of
the x-axis, which typically is zero, one
mathematical trick we can use is to grab
a curve as a whole and run a reverse
math operation. basically to multiply
the curve by a negative one and it will
flip it across the x-axis. That works
here as well and I can show you how to
do that. So, let me go ahead and just
grab a curve that's maybe centered more
closely around zero. This will work. So,
here we have the location in X and you
can see that zero runs right through
almost the middle of the curve. If I
were to select one of the keys, you'll
see up here we have the frame number and
then here we have the value on the
curve. If I grab the entire curve, one
of the things that's going to happen,
everything gets grabbed. Therefore,
these both say multiple values. Now, I
don't really want to mess with the left
text field because that's going to
change the frame number. And these are
all on different frames. So, that does
not help me. But here, if I were to type
in a value of zero, it would zero out
every key. Not what we want in this
case. So, I'll undo that. But what I can
do is I can run a mathematical operation
to reverse every single one of these
keys on the curve. So if I say uh
multiply= -1 or asterisk equal minus1
that will multiply the current value by
its inverse wh or multiply by negative
1. Therefore inverting it is maybe how I
should say it. And so that will flip the
curve vertically. But that does not help
us if our curve is not actually centered
around zero. And so if I go back to one
of my rotation channels, maybe the
rotate x I was messing with earlier. Um,
if I were to do that here, that's not
helpful because you'll see all of these
values take place somewhere between90
or so and 130. So, if I were to take
this curve and multiply it by -1, the
curve is going to disappear. And what
ends up happening is it actually just
changed from 90 to130 to positive 90 and
positive30. So, it's like way way
different. Not really helpful in this
case. This is a very long and drawn out
way to just say, "Hey, with the new
lattice tool, all you have to do if you
want to just flip a curve around itself
is go to the lattice tool with that
curve selected and just double click in
this blank space
and you're done. Super super easy. I
don't believe that works with the
transform tool or the selection tool.
You need to specifically just jump into
the lattice mode to do this. But it's so
quick and easy and we'll it'll just use
its own top and bottom bounds to flip
within that range. Super handy. Love
that a lot. And then one other thing I
want to show you is how to scale a curve
using the lattice tool as well. And you
might just think, oh, it's as simple as
just grabbing the edge and dragging it
in. And yes, you are right about that.
But there is a bit of a caveat that I
want to give. I'll just use the rotate Z
channel to show you this. But if I want
to take this curve and just scale it
down, make the whole thing faster. Um,
I'll go ahead and start us off by taking
this curve, going to the filters. I'm
going to just bake this down on one. So,
I have a ton of different keys, right?
Keys on every frame. Too many keys. Now,
if you've ever scaled something down in
Maya that was baked down, you would
potentially remember that if you try to
push a bunch of keys closer together,
then you actually have frames to
support. Maybe you have got, you know,
10 key frames of data and you want to
compress it down to five frames. That's
two keys per frame. How's that going to
work? What will happen in Maya is Maya
will basically have two keys that are
fighting over one spot, one frame, and
it'll give you a soft error and it'll
say, "Hey, we don't know like which one
is supposed to take priority. We have to
delete one of the two. We weren't sure
what to do, so we just we're going to
leave it for you to deal with, which you
know might be nice because it's not
going to make any decisions for you, but
at the same time, then you have to do
all that work yourself." Now, in the
past, Unreal would kind of just put both
of them more or less on the same key
because it could support that math for
that kind of behavior. But now, it's got
a much more animation friendly approach.
If I take this curve, this full set of
keys and I just want to compress it. By
default, with the default settings, it's
actually not going to be that helpful.
If I go to the transform mode and I just
take this actually what I'll do is uh
I'll move this this pivot point and say
I want to scale it from the first frame.
So I'll just take this whole thing and
go whoosh and I'll start to push it. And
what you'll see is all the keys are
starting to bunch up on each other and
I'm starting to get a bunch of keys
starting to like lump up on the same
frames. And as long as I'm holding down
the mouse you can see that the curve
profile is getting really wonky as it
tries to sort it out in real time. As
soon as I let go though, it will sort of
smart snap. It'll sort of figure out,
hey, how do we reduce this whole set of
keys that you have selected and, you
know, not make it super awful. And here
it did a pretty good job. But in some
cases, it may not give you the exact
curve you want because as you are
scaling this down and maybe if you're
doing this with a large amount of key
frames on a bunch of different controls,
you are reducing the amount of data that
you're actually preserving because it's
got to get rid of something. you're
compressing too much. It's got to it's
got to get rid of some of what won't
fit. Instead of doing it that way, what
I would recommend is you do the same
selection. You grab whatever controls
you're messing with and this time turn
off the time snapping by hitting this
little magnet button. You are now
unlocking the sort of safety net we have
here that allows me to scrub and go
from, you know, frame 101, 106, 107, 10,
whatever. I'm on whole key frames which
we which we want. But if I unlock this
by taking off time snapping now when I
scrub, I'm allowed to scrub in between
the key frames. So if I you'll see here
that I can take a key from frame 109
specifically and I can actually drag it
anywhere in between frame 109 and 110.
Not really what you want, right? You
don't usually want to have the ability
to do this because now we've got nonhole
key frames. But bear with me. There is a
method to this madness. If I now have
time unlocked and I grab my curve to do
my scaling with now when I go ahead and
grab my transform key and compress it
down, as I scale it, it will keep the
exact same curve profile. And you can
see here that I'm not having any weird
recalculation happening while I do my my
scaling. And when I go to release it,
the curve stays exactly as it was. This
is a really nice sort of phase one step.
But now, you know, we have a bunch of
different key frames sitting in between
our whole frames because here's frame
109, this white line, and then here's
frame 110. There's a lot of keys. in
this case, three specific keys that are
all sitting inside of that one frame,
which we don't want. So, what do we do?
Well, there's a brand new tool for this
in 5.6 that you'll be able to use going
forward into 5.7 and on. If you select a
curve, right click, and go into filter,
or even just hit this button for filter,
you'll find something called smart snap.
You can also just rightclick and find it
in the menu here, or the hotkey is H.
And what smart snap will do is unlike
Maya where it'll sort of get stuck when
it has to make a decision and it says I
don't know which one you want. Smart
snap will take this entire curve set its
own key frames on every whole frame and
then delete everything else that was in
between. So it gives you your most
accurate version of the scaled key or
scaled curve in this case. And just to
be on the safe side, I'm also going to
combine it by right-clicking and say
buffer curve. By doing a buffer curve,
I'm snapshotting the current state of
this curve so I can compare it to the
result I'm about to have. So now I've
done my buffer curve. I can select this
curve. I can go to smart snap. I can hit
apply. And that is now going to reduce
my key frame to whole frames only. And
so now if I take a look at it, you can
see that this curve is now keyed on just
on ones on, you know, a key for every
frame. No weird in between keys. And if
I select the curve, I'll make sure I go
into my view mode and I have buffer
curves turned on. You can see what the
old curve looked like with this kind of
gray ghost behind what the current
version of the curve is. And you can see
I'm very very close. If for some reason,
you know, in this case here, it's like,
oh, I actually I wanted this to be a
sharper drop off. This was meant to be,
you know, very specific timing. Well,
then great. Like I can come in here and
I can make my adjustments and, you know,
tweak my curve handles or, you know,
whatever I'm going to do. But that's the
new SmartStep tool. And if you if you do
this full workflow, make sure you
reenable time snapping so you don't end
up putting new key frames on non-hole
frames. But what it allows you to do is
take a curve that has a little bit too
dense of key frame data and save out
that curve profile on the whole frames
and then clear out everything in
between. It's a really cool way to
handle that situation and I'm a big fan
of the way that Unreal actually
evaluates that. There are a ton of other
